Dear Ms. Prudhomme:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the Modified
Implementation, Sustainability and Exit Plan (MISEP) and your contract.

ALLEGATION:
Two youth placed at the facility have been engaging in sexual intercourse. Staff
were aware and safety planned to keep the youth in different groups within the
house. However, youth were still able to engage in intercourse when staff were
distracted. A request was made to move one youth to a different house and the
facility has not responded.
INVESTIGATION:
On May 5, 2021 it was reported to me that 22 youth out of 44 had tested positive for
COVID-19. Based on this information, this special investigation was not completed
with in-person contacts, rather completed virtually.
On May 6, 2021 I interviewed Chief Administrator 3, Youth A (female, age 15), and
Administrator 4 with DHHS Investigator 1. All were interviewed using Microsoft
Teams.
Youth A said on three occasions she and Youth B (male) had sexual intercourse at
the facility. She said the first occasion was on March 23, 2021. Youth A and Youth B
were in the common area and Former Staff 10 was supervising.
Youth A said she and Youth B “had sex” on Saturday, April 24, 2021 and on Sunday,
April 25, 2021 in the bathroom on the living unit. Youth A said both times she had
sex with Youth B Direct Care Worker 5, Direct Care Worker 6, and Direct Care
Worker 7 were supervising seven youth. Youth A said that she and Youth B did not
get caught on Saturday but ended up getting caught on Sunday.
On May 12, 2021, another Microsoft Teams meeting was set up with DHHS
Investigator 1 and Eagle Village. We reviewed training and discipline of Direct Care
Supervisor 8, Direct Care Worker 5, Direct Care Worker 6 and Direct Care Worker 7.
Direct Care Worker 5 was interviewed she said she and Direct Care Worker 6 and
Direct Care Worker 7 were supervising 8 or 9 youth. Direct Care Worker 5 said she
was unaware of Youth B need for one-to-one supervision. Direct Care Worker 5 said

that when Youth A came out of the bathroom and the door was closed, the light was
turned off, then the light came back on, as seen under the door.
Program Manager 12 was interviewed by Microsoft Teams on May 12, 2021. He
said that Youth B was on a one-to-one “as needed”. He said the one-to-one was
based on Youth B being assaultive.
Eagle Village requested one-to-one supervisor of Youth B in a request dated March
23, 2021, which requested up 16 hours of one-to one per day “as needed”. Eagle
Village billed for 91.5 hours in March 2021 and 214.05 hours in April 2021.One-to-
one hours started in March on the 25th. Eagle Village did not bill for one-to-one hours
between April 22 and April 26th. They billed for 13 hours of one-to-one on Friday,
April 22, 2021 and 11.5 hours on Monday, April 26, 2021.
Administrator 4 was interviewed by telephone on June 15, 2021. She said the
criteria for one to one for Youth B was based on his assaultive and aggressive
behavior. The decision to put Youth B on one to one was made by Direct Care
Supervisor 8 and Youth B’s Therapist 13. Administrator 4 said the decision for one to
one was communicated by Direct Care Supervisor 8. Administrator 4 said the one to
one was for aggressive behavior and not based on Youth A and Youth B’s sexual
behavior. She said that Youth B was only on one to one when it was deemed
important to keep other youth, staff and Youth B safe from Youth B’s assaultive
behavior.
The letter requesting one to one, dated March 23, 2021, for Youth B read in part as
follows:
This letter is to request compensation for individual supervision of (Youth B)
during waking hours, maximum of 16 hours, as needed. This request is due to
the recent behavioral/aggressive behaviors that (Youth B) has been displaying.
(Youth B) has been struggling with demonstrating safe and consistent positive
behaviors. He continues to become escalated quickly, resulting in him being
physically assaultive towards staff and on one occasion a peer. (Youth B)
assaulted staff on the following dates: 2/21/2021, 3/10/2021, and 3/17/2021.
Charges were pressed by staff on the 3/17/2021 incident. On 3/22/2012, (Youth
B) physically assaulted a peer while they were in school, during this incident he
also bit a staff member in the head when the staff was attempting to get (Youth B)
off the other peer that he was attacking. Charges were pressed by this peer on
(Youth B) on 3/23/2021. (Youth B)’s behaviors have continued to fluctuate with
remaining unsafe and assaultive when he becomes upset.
Direct Care Worker 7 was interviewed over Microsoft Teams on May 12, 2021. He
said he lost track of Youth B and was checking every room on Sunday, April 25,
2021. He said he looked for two minutes. Direct Care Worker 7 said he thought that
Youth B was in the bathroom first, then Youth A went in while Youth B was in there.

The next staff to be interviewed was Direct Care Supervisor 8 over Microsoft Teams
on May 12, 2021. Direct Care Supervisor 8 said he thought Youth A and Youth B
were acting suspicious on March 23, 2021 and he then reviewed the video and saw
that Youth A and Youth B had sexual intercourse on the couch in the television area.
Direct Care Supervisor 8 said he reviewed the video on March 23, 2021 right after
he felt Youth A and Youth B were acting suspicious. Direct Care Supervisor 8 then
confronted Youth A and Youth B and they were required to stay apart with staff
between them. The letter requesting one to one for Youth B was dated March 23,
2021. This letter cited three assaults on staff and one assault on another youth as
the reason for the one-to-one request.
Former Staff 10 was supposed to be supervising Youth A and Youth B and was
sitting nearby. Direct Care Supervisor 8 said that Youth B was on a one-to-one
supervision as needed. Direct Care Supervisor 8 said he was not working on April
24 and April 25, but Youth B was still on a one-to-one as needed on those dates.
Direct Care Worker 6 was interviewed over Microsoft Teams with DHHS Investigator
1 on May 12, 2021. He said he was in the office area doing paperwork on Sunday
when Youth B was caught coming out of the bathroom after Youth A was in there.
He said that there were nine youth and three staff at the facility.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency’s
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
ANALYSIS: Despite having three staff to nine youth, staff were not providing
the required supervision of Youth A and Youth B, evidenced by
the youth having sexual contact three times over a two-day
period, twice after the facility was aware it occurred the first
time. Additionally, the facility lacked sufficient supervision and
oversight of the youth, staff and unit, evidenced by the
supervisor being aware of the initial instance of sexual acting
out and not placing Youth B on one-to-one supervision, not
implementing a safety plan and not providing supervision to staff
to prevent further incidents.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
INVESTIGATION:
I received an email from DHHS Worker 11 which had a letter from Youth A to Youth
B. The envelope was addressed by Youth A to Youth B in his new placement. Eagle
Village did not have the authority to provide Youth B’s contact information to Youth
A. Youth A, age 15 is below the age of consent for sexual behaviors in Michigan.
Youth B is above the age of consent.
The letter from Youth A to Youth B was dated May 7, 2021 and it was postmarked
on May 17, 2021. Youth B was placed in another facility on May 6, 2021. The letter
was in an Eagle Village envelope and it was after the three incidents of sexual
intercourse between Youth A and Youth B.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4130 Privacy and confidentiality.
(1) An institution shall assure resident and parent privacy
and confidentiality and shall protect residents from
exploitation.
ANALYSIS: Eagle Village did not protect Youth B or Youth A by providing
unauthorized contact information.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
INVESTIGATION:
Under Eagle Village’s policy for compliance with the child protection law it reads in
part:
1. Immediately notify the DHHS Child Protective Services--Centralized Intake
Division at (855)444-3911 and the referring worker by phone that physical
abuse, sexual abuse, or neglect has been suspected.
Eagle Village was aware of three times that a youth under their direct supervision
had sexual relations with one another in the residence with staff present, and they
did not follow their policy of reporting to central intake.

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4131 Compliance with child protection law; development of plan
required.
The licensee shall develop and implement a written plan to
assure compliance with the child protection law, 1975 PA
238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
ANALYSIS: Eagle Village did not follow their policy regarding compliance
with the child protection law.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that there be no change to the licensing status of this private
child caring institution upon the receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan.
